Thank you very much for such detailed information on my tsuba. As a
sidenot=
e, would this particular tsuba have any monetary value?
Although, if it did=
, I don't think I would sell it. I have grown
rather attached to it - it ha=
s a certain sentimental value - my
great-grandfather brought it back from t=
he China station before the
first world war. He visited Japan while there a=
pparently.

Patrick.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Dr John P Lisse=
nden"
<docliss@...> wrote:
>
> Dear Patrick
> 
> Yes indeed - one of the Na=
mban group and probably made by a casting 
> process in the early-mid C19. =
 This group is characterised by its 
> openwork and undercutting; the commo=
n presence of affronted dragons 
> with the tama jewel; and the atypically =
shaped seppa-dai.  All of 
> these are present on your tsuba.
> 
> I would =
have expected a tsuba of this type to be of iron, but some 
> were cast in =
bronze.  Interestingly these are unexpectedly attracted 
> by a magnet, but=
 the admixture of up to 30% of iron to bronze in 
> order to reduce the cos=
t of the expensive alloy was not unknown.  
> Also, iron was a common inclu=
sion in naturally occurring copper ore 
> 
> Regards, John L.
> 
> 
> 
> --=
